name: Tryptophan
summary: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor to serotonin, melatonin, and niacin, with potential roles in mood regulation, sleep, and stress resilience.
description: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid obtained from dietary sources and is metabolized into serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (vitamin B3). It plays a key role in regulating mood, sleep-wake cycles, and stress response. Supplementation has been studied for depression, insomnia, premenstrual dysphoric disorder, and seasonal affective disorder, though clinical evidence varies. Its use is limited by competition with other amino acids for transport across the blood-brain barrier, and high doses can cause side effects. Tryptophan supplementation should be distinguished from 5-HTP, another serotonin precursor.

metadata.natural_source: Protein-rich foods such as poultry, eggs, dairy, soy, nuts, seeds
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

contraindications: Concurrent use with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOIs (risk of serotonin syndrome)
History of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (rare but linked historically with contaminated tryptophan supplements)
monitoring_required: Signs of serotonin syndrome if combined with serotonergic drugs

items: May support sleep onset and quality through melatonin production
Adjunctive support for mood disorders via serotonin synthesis
Potential benefit for seasonal affective disorder

sections.text: Tryptophan is converted by tryptophan hydroxylase into 5-HTP and then serotonin, which regulates mood, anxiety, and sleep. Serotonin can also be metabolized into melatonin, influencing circadian rhythms. Additionally, tryptophan can be diverted into the kynurenine pathway under inflammatory conditions, which may affect mood and neurobiology.

adult.note: Clinical studies often use 1–2 g/day; lower doses (250–500 mg) may be combined with carbohydrate to aid absorption.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended outside of clinical supervision.

sections.text: Sleep benefits may be seen within days; mood effects may take several weeks.

serious: Serotonin syndrome when combined with serotonergic drugs

other: Do not combine with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOIs, or other serotonergic agents without medical supervision.
Use with caution in individuals with liver disease or eosinophilia history.

items: Signs of serotonin syndrome if on serotonergic medications

sections.pregnancy: Insufficient safety data; avoid unless supervised
sections.geriatrics: Generally well tolerated; start low due to sedation risk

sections.text: No formal taper required; may discontinue abruptly, though sleep quality may decrease.

items: Essential amino acid—must be obtained from diet.
High-protein meals may reduce CNS availability due to competition with other large neutral amino acids.
5-HTP is a downstream metabolite sometimes used instead, though with different pharmacokinetics and risks.
